Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Fluid Flow-Assisted Assembly of Solar Cell Devices
Award.AbstractNarration:
Organic photovoltaics (OPVs) hold great promise as a solar energy conversion technology which can be easily mass produced and is cheap enough to offer electricity at a price comparable to power generated from traditional coal-fired power plants. Furthermore, the potential for use with flexible substrates opens new opportunities for integration of solar cells with architecture and urban infrastructure. While the advantages of OPVs are attractive, the technology is just emerging from its infancy and has yet to reach power conversion efficiencies exceeding 10%. Most of the critical physics intrinsic to achieving the necessary efficiencies occur in the active layer of a device which is composed of organic polymer semiconductors. This project aims to improve device efficiency by investigating the benefits of controlling the assembly and organization of the active layer at the molecular scale. The research will be conducted under the mentorship of Professor Chih-I Wu at National Taiwan University who has extensive experience with OPVs and similar semiconductor technology and is ideally suited to host this research.

Critical processes in the OPV active layer include charge-carrier generation through light absorption and charge-carrier collection due to exciton diffusion, dissociation, and transport to opposite contacts. Excitons?excited, yet still bound pairs of positive and negative charge carriers?in organic materials have relatively low diffusion lengths and mobilities compared to charge transport in typical solid-state photovoltaic semiconductors. As such, the strategy of increasing active layer thickness in order to increase photon interaction with the material leads to lost efficiency due to carrier recombination, often negating the strategy?s intentions. One such solution is to increase effective optical thickness while retaining minimal physical thickness by integration of metallic nanoparticles into the polymer matrix. Solutions such as this, however, are still often deposited by spin-coating, which provides excellent control of active layer thickness, but little control with regard to mesoscale architecture. Recent work at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign has demonstrated enhancement of optoelectronic properties in organic semiconducting polymers due to molecular alignment via microfluidics. This research aims to achieve unprecedented efficiencies through the synthesis of metallic nanoparticle doping with microfluidic directed assembly. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Ministry of Science and Technology of Taiwan.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As the demand for low-carbon footprint energy rises, increasing research is being conducted toward finding low-cost alternatives to conventional silicon solar cells. Among these low-cost alternatives is the class of solid-state cells known as hybrid organometal perovskites. Perovskites are materials which crystalize in an ABX3 structure, ideally as a cubic structure with corner-sharing BX6 octahedra where the A ion is located at the cuboctahedral interstices. In the instance of these experiments we have used perovskites where B is Pb2+, X is Cl-, and A is the organic buckeyball compound [6,6]-phenyl C61-butyric acid methyl ester (PC60BM). We created multiple solar cells varying numbers of PEDOT:PSS (an exciton hole transport material) using the VASP method and measure current density as a function of voltage to determine the configuration with optimal power conversion efficiency (PCE). We also investigated the possibility of improving PCE via increased grain size by using CNC-milled-PMMA microfluidic devices with planar extensional flow to subject perovskite precursors to a uniform force field while crystalizing. The intention for this flow method is that the initial crystallization seeds will form more uniformly and lead to a more uniform grain size distribution after annealing.

               Such microfluidic devices utilize the laminar flow caused by reducing channels to microscale dimensions. From cell and particle sorting to investigations of reaction kinetics, the linearity associated with low Reynolds number flow has proved invaluable. Furthermore, recent work has taken advantage of the force fields of creeping flow in a cross slot design to physically align peptide polymer as it is formed from its monomer constituents. Yet, such complex reactions leave much to be inference when viewed under an optical microscope. Most methods which have been developed to date for achieving liquid layers compatible with the extremely high vacuum conditions required for TEM can be divided into two families: 1) Lab on chip designs involve hermetically sealing all liquid on a self-contained chip. These methods are able to achieve TEM-resolution images of liquid—and even flowing—samples; however, this gain comes at the cost of complex sealing processes and low throughput. 2) More recent flow cell designs force a flow of solution between electron-transparent windows separated by spacers. O-rings and mechanical force separate the top and bottom windows from the rest of the cell, protecting the sample and the microscope from solution leakage and allowing there to be input and output sample lines that connect to the microscope exterior. While these designs allow samples to be viewed under flow conditions with relatively high throughput, the geometry of the cells involve multiple flow paths leading to uncertainty in liquid layer thickness and flow direction. Recent work had sought to incorporate the benefits of these two design families by using nanofabrication techniques to create cells with well-defined flow paths. However, the definition of the flow paths to date is limited to one dimension. It was thus another goal of this project to create a nanofluidic device such that reactions unique to complex two-dimensional flow geometries might be investigated with nanoscale resolution. We thus developed a proof of concept design for a nanofluidic device compatible with the TEM environment. In the interest of simplicity, typical nanofabrication methods were avoided in favor of simple planar deposition techniques. Simplified schematics of the device design and assembly format are attached.


Last Modified: 02/28/2016
Modified by: Lawrence Valverde
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: As the demand for low-carbon footprint energy rises, increasing research is being conducted toward finding low-cost alternatives to conventional silicon solar cells. Among these low-cost alternatives is the class of solid-state cells known as hybrid organometal perovskites. Perovskites are materials which crystalize in an ABX3 structure, ideally as a cubic structure with corner-sharing BX6 octahedra where the A ion is located at the cuboctahedral interstices. In the instance of these experiments we have used perovskites where B is Pb2+, X is Cl-, and A is the organic buckeyball compound [6,6]-phenyl C61-butyric acid methyl ester (PC60BM). We created multiple solar cells varying numbers of PEDOT:PSS (an exciton hole transport material) using the VASP method and measure current density as a function of voltage to determine the configuration with optimal power conversion efficiency (PCE). We also investigated the possibility of improving PCE via increased grain size by using CNC-milled-PMMA microfluidic devices with planar extensional flow to subject perovskite precursors to a uniform force field while crystalizing. The intention for this flow method is that the initial crystallization seeds will form more uniformly and lead to a more uniform grain size distribution after annealing. Such microfluidic devices utilize the laminar flow caused by reducing channels to microscale dimensions. From cell and particle sorting to investigations of reaction kinetics, the linearity associated with low Reynolds number flow has proved invaluable. Furthermore, recent work has taken advantage of the force fields of creeping flow in a cross slot design to physically align peptide polymer as it is formed from its monomer constituents. Yet, such complex reactions leave much to be inference when viewed under an optical microscope. Most methods which have been developed to date for achieving liquid layers compatible with the extremely high vacuum conditions required for TEM can be divided into two families: 1) Lab on chip designs involve hermetically sealing all liquid on a self-contained chip. These methods are able to achieve TEM-resolution images of liquid—and even flowing—samples; however, this gain comes at the cost of complex sealing processes and low throughput. 2) More recent flow cell designs force a flow of solution between electron-transparent windows separated by spacers. O-rings and mechanical force separate the top and bottom windows from the rest of the cell, protecting the sample and the microscope from solution leakage and allowing there to be input and output sample lines that connect to the microscope exterior. While these designs allow samples to be viewed under flow conditions with relatively high throughput, the geometry of the cells involve multiple flow paths leading to uncertainty in liquid layer thickness and flow direction. Recent work had sought to incorporate the benefits of these two design families by using nanofabrication techniques to create cells with well-defined flow paths. However, the definition of the flow paths to date is limited to one dimension. It was thus another goal of this project to create a nanofluidic device such that reactions unique to complex two-dimensional flow geometries might be investigated with nanoscale resolution. We thus developed a proof of concept design for a nanofluidic device compatible with the TEM environment. In the interest of simplicity, typical nanofabrication methods were avoided in favor of simple planar deposition techniques. Simplified schematics of the device design and assembly format are attached. Last Modified: 02/28/2016 Submitted by: Lawrence Valverde
